text: Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Uh some data that said people who are on Enzalutamide stay on Enzalutamide and get these drugs uh may have a higher response rate, and that’s what we are testing. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: We have done this already in fifteen men and I think three people benefited for a period of time, relatively short. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: But still benefited and so they did not have Enzalutamide or the Xtandi, so we’re doing fifteen more who have Xtandi uh and seeing whether or not it’s a higher response because of that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So technically your ARV7 right now is positive enough to go on, your PSA is rising, you’re on the Xtandi, okay. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: The worry is the lungs, okay because this is a treatment that if we turn on your immune system so loud it can attack your normal body. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: So you can get a non-infectious pneumonia and get really short of breath and it fills up with scar tissue and s tuff like that and that we have to stop with steroids.

text: Patient: Run down. Yeah, it did, it was making me really tired. Doctor: Yeah. text: Family Member: Mm, hmm. (pause) Doctor: Yes. Family Member: Okay. And uh oh one more question. Doctor: Um hum. Family Member: Now with these injections, G____ said he won’t be able to have an erection or any of that. Is that even with like using you talk about using Viagra or something else before, even with that you can’t? Doctor: Uh well you could try. There’s no harm in trying. Uh sometimes they depress your drive, your libido, you desire, and so most men just don’t care that much. There’s some men who do care but no matter what you do you can’t knock their drive down. Doctor: And if that’s the case, you can, you can do injection treatments. Did he mention that? Family Member: No, but I remember you mentioned that once before. Okay. Doctor: So that’s actually, keep that in mind. Family Member: Okay, okay. And what hormone is he getting that decreases the… Doctor: It’s called Lupron or LHRH. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Luteinizing hormone-releasing hormone LHRH.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: You could get regular Taxotere, Taxotere forever if you wanted to. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Now your hands and feet won’t let you do it because you might get numb. Doctor: You kind of pretty much know if you are on the vitamin C though. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because you do get flushing and you know kind of like what you think about high-dose vitamins. text: Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: And on a clinical trial, we don’t know if more is better, but that third drug, if you were to get it, starts to kill cancer cells. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: If you don’t get it- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: - you still have two things that we know kill cancer cells that make people live longer. Patient: Right. Doctor: And so do we just sort of like stay low or if you get better, if the prostate shrinks and we are able to get the catheter out, then we did the right thing. Or if time goes on and you still have trouble getting that catheter out, uh would radiation help? Is it because the drugs aren’t doing what they need to do to shrink it to allow you to have a reasonable channel to get the pee out? Um and that’s sort of – before when we had chemo and before we had these super hormones, some of us would send you to radiation. And then now we don’t know because you can’t get the radiation and the chemo and the hormone all at the same time. Family Member: Right. Doctor: Because that’s just way too much. Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Now, is he going to have a body scan at one point to see what’s happening with the cancer cells? Uh she should have that body scan uh that Dr. ____ said that it’s . Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
